Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 45355-001 
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
November 2011 
 
 
 
Regional Forum on Public Sector Accounting  
(Financed by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
CTL  –  Controller’s Department 
DMC  –  developing member country 
  IFAC  –  International Federation of Accountants 
IPSAS  –  International Public Sector Accounting Standards 
  IPSASB  –  International Public Sector Accounting Standards Board 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
       
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—Capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector   –  Public sector management 
Themes   –  Regional cooperation and integration, capacity development

Vice-President  B. N. Lohani, Finance and Administration 
Controller  H.S. Jung, Controller’s Department (CTL) 
Assistant  C.S. Kim, Accounting Division, CTL 
Controller 
   
Team leader  D. Nishimoto, Senior Financial Control Specialist, CTL 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) depends on developing member countries’ (DMCs) 
own financial management system in its lending, so it is critical for them to have sound public 
sector  accounting  systems. This regional  capacity  development  technical  assistance1  (TA) 
seeks to improve the structure of public sector management by strengthening the accounting 
and reporting systems of governments and public sector enterprises. It is also designed to 
achieve  one  of  the  key  objectives  of  Strategy  2020—promoting  regional  cooperation  and 
integration. 
 
 2.  The International Public Sector Accounting Standards Board (IPSASB) is a standards-
setting body designated by, and operating under, the International Federation of Accountants 
(IFAC).  One of its main functions is to develop financial reporting standards for the public 
sector.  Standards  set  by  the  IPSASB  provide  the  foundation  for  achieving  the  long-term 
objectives of (i) moving toward cash or accrual basis accounting2 and (ii) improving the quality 
and reliability of accounting and financial reporting for the public sector.   
 
3.  Since  1997,  ADB  has  been  providing  technical  assistance  to  support  IPSASB’s 
standard-setting  program  through  the  regional  policy  and  advisory  TA  for  Public  Sector 
Accounting Standards (Phase 4)3 in developing accounting standards for public sectors. The 
Controller’s Department (CTL) has been participating in the IPSASB forums and task forces for 
reviewing some of the International Public Sector Accounting Standards (IPSAS). The IPSASB 
has been emphasizing the need for more outreach programs to provide support for building the 
capacity of DMCs by adopting the IPSAS and improving their overall financial reporting and 
management framework. This capacity development TA aims to complement the policy and 
advisory TA and to assist DMCs in formulating plans to improve their government accounting 
arrangements,  particularly  in  legal  or  institutional  structures,  standard-setting  processes, 
information technology systems, and capacity building programs for government officials. This 
paper  defines  the  output,  methodology,  and  key  activities  of  the  project.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The recent global financial turmoil has emphasized the urgent need to have global 
accounting standards and professionally qualified accountants with appropriate technical skills 
in public sectors. The IFAC has been urging the Group of Twenty (G-20) Finance Ministers and 
Central Bank Governors for financial reforms in the public sector and stressing the need for 
sustainability in public finances. It has promoted the importance of the accounting profession to 
provide greater transparency and accountability in public sector finances by adopting a common 
set of accounting standards.  
 
5.  Best practices identified by IFAC promote similar entities to maintain accounting systems 
that enable each to prepare financial information in a timely, consistent, and comparable format. 
However, many DMCs do not have robust accounting standards and systems for financial 
reporting  and  management.  Recognizing  such  needs,  the  IPSASB  has  been  developing 
accounting standards that will allow governments to establish the accounting framework for their

spent while for accrual basis accounting, revenue and expense are recorded when they are earned or incurred, 
regardless of when cash is exchanged.

public sector. The adoption of the IPSAS by governments will improve both the quality and 
comparability of financial information reported by public sector entities around the world.  
 
6.  The CTL has been participating in the IPSASB forums and task forces to review some of 
the standards. It has also been working with DMCs in disseminating knowledge for maintaining 
sound fiduciary controls and accounting frameworks for a more effective administration and 
monitoring of ADB’s loans. However, there has been no extensive cross-border platform to 
strengthen the overall government accounting framework. 
 
7.  This  TA  aims  to  assist  DMCs  in  strengthening  their  government  accounting  and 
reporting. It will address DMCs’ needs to improve government accounting standards and related 
information  technology  systems  by  (i)  establishing  legal  or  institutional  arrangements,  (ii) 
developing capacity in public sector accounting, (iii) establishing a platform for exchange of 
knowledge and focus on key issues, (iv) and organizing seminars and specific workshops on 
strengthening government accounting.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The  TA  is  expected  to  enhance  the  awareness  of  DMC  government  officials  on 
international accounting standards and practices to improve their financial reporting, which 
would benefit from improved transparency and accountability. This knowledge would improve 
the quality of financial management and reduce the risks of financial reporting fraud.  
 
9.  Cross-border  interaction  will  support  collaborative  capacity  development  and  enable 
DMC  officials  to  increase  their  awareness  and  understanding  of  public  sector  accounting 
practices and to gain access to market developments and best practices. This TA will improve 
ADB’s understanding of the type and scope of assistances required by DMCs in government 
accounting and strengthen its insights and knowledge in this area. The TA will allow the CTL to 
liaise with other relevant areas in ADB to (i) conduct accounting forums for DMC government 
officials, (ii) build awareness and capacity on accounting related challenges and issues, and (iii) 
provide assistance to DMCs in strengthening the government accounting framework.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will be implemented in consultation with other relevant areas in ADB to assess 
the readiness of the DMCs to enhance their government accounting framework and to identify 
participants from selected DMCs to achieve the appropriate mix of government and public 
sector enterprise officials. As a first step, one or two forums will be organized for targeted 
DMCs. These forums will serve as a platform for government officials to share information and 
knowledge relating to accounting practices and systems used in DMCs. Progress reports, news 
releases, and survey results will be used to monitor the activities as well as provide information 
to the participants. 
 
11.  With the TA, ADB will perform a broad review of the current accounting practices in the 
public sector area of DMCs. ADB will select two or three DMCs and assist in designing their 
plan and preparing and implementing their government accounting reforms. These results will 
be presented in a regional forum of relevant government officials. The study paper identifying 
good examples and success factors will be adjusted to reflect the results of discussions from the

3 
forum and will be circulated to participating DMCs. Also, ADB will conduct advisory studies in 
the public sector accounting of a few countries (on a voluntary basis). 
 
12.  The  forum  will  allow  participants  to  gain  a  better  understanding  of  the  current 
developments in the IPSAS and increase capacity in improving their financial reporting through 
knowledge sharing and cooperation among participating countries and institutions. The TA aims 
to  collaborate  closely  with  exemplary  countries  and  to  disseminate  the  experience  and 
knowledge  to  other  DMCs.  It  is  anticipated  that  the  DMCs  with  less  developed  financial 
reporting practices will  gain from knowledge sharing with countries that have more robust 
accounting framework and information technology systems, such as the Republic of Korea.  
 
13.  The forum and initial study will be used to identify specific areas of challenges faced by 
DMCs in strengthening government accounting frameworks and adopting the IPSAS. The TA 
aims to design customized workshops and training based on the specific interests of a country 
or group of countries. The workshops will address these countries’ concerns and issues and be 
designed  to  discuss,  find  solutions,  and  develop  road  maps  to  strengthen  government 
accounting frameworks.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  the  Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  and 
administered by ADB.  The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA project, which will be implemented by the 
Accounting  Division  of  the  CTL.  Consultants  will  be  used  in  the  areas  of  public  sector 
accounting research and forum coordination. A team of accounting staff will coordinate and 
manage the consultants’ activities and coordinate the overall TA project. The project will be 
carried out from December 2011 to December 2014.   
 
16.  The TA will require two international consultants for 10–12 person-months and one 
national consultant for about 12 person-months. The international consultants will comprise 
financial management and accounting specialists whose main task is to facilitate workshops and 
forums  in  public  sector  accounting.  The  national  consultant  will  provide  overall  support  in 
research, workshops, and forums coordination. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
17.  Consultants  will  be  used  throughout  the  TA  program,  and  outputs  will  include  (i) 
developing questionnaires, surveys, and study reports; (ii) assist in conducting forums and 
workshops  as  facilitators  and  speakers;  (iii)  undertaking  ad  hoc  projects  in  research, 
consultation,  and  advisement;  and  (iv)  providing  administrative  support  to  ADB  staff  and 
international consultants. In addition, the TA funds will be used to cover the expenses of the 
forums and workshops, which include the venues, travel and accommodation for participants, 
and other miscellaneous administrative and support costs.

4   
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering Regional Forum on Public Sector Accounting technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and 
 
Knowledge Partnership Fund for Public Sector Accounting, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The regional capacity development technical assistance will require consulting services 
carried out by two international consultants and one national consultant. 
A.  Public  Sector  Accounting  Experts  (2 international staff, 10–12 person-months on 
retainer, 2011–2014) 
2.  The experts should have (i) solid experience and in-depth knowledge of international 
public  sector  accounting  standards;1  (ii)  extensive  knowledge  of  Asia and  the  Pacific; (iii) 
experience  working  with  government  officials  in  the  region;  (iv)  a  good  reputation  and 
experience in similar assignments; and (v) a university or post-graduate degree in accounting, 
business, economics, or a related field. The accounting experts will do the following: 
 
(i)  design and conduct surveys on existing accounting practices and identify specific 
areas of challenges faced by developing member countries (DMCs);  
(ii)  collaborate  with  the  International  Public  Sector  Accounting  Standards  Board, 
regional governments, and other multilateral development banks for knowledge 
sharing and harmonization; 
(iii)  coordinate timetables, programs, lists of participants, logistical arrangements, and 
other necessary provisions with DMC governments;  
(iv)  work with selected DMCs to share and discuss more technical topics that are 
focused on specific areas that were identified;  
(v)  design questionnaires for each regional forum and workshop to assess the status 
and  training  needs  of  the  target  DMCs  on  the  International  Public  Sector 
Accounting Standards; 
(vi)  formulate forum and workshop programs to meet the DMCs’ requirements based 
on the results of the questionnaires; 
(vii)  participate in forums and workshops as resource speaker and/or facilitator; 
(viii)  prepare forums, workshops, and training materials; 
(ix)  assist in selecting and inviting resource speakers for forums and workshops; 
(x)  prepare progress and summary reports for all forums and workshops including 
achievements versus targets and future improvements, among others; 
(xi)  develop a study report related to public sector accounting in the region and the 
future involvement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on these issues; 
(xii)  undertake ad-hoc projects in research, consultation, and/or advisement on subjects 
per request; and 
(xiii)  organize workshops and/or training programs for specific DMCs to develop road 
maps to strengthen government accounting and address their concerns to meet 
requirements. 
B.  Research Associate and Forum Coordinator (1 national, about 12 person-months on 
retainer, 2011–2014) 
3.  The  coordinator  should  have  (i)  substantial  experience  planning  and  managing 
workshops and conferences and managing databases; (ii) strong experience organizing events 
in the public sector, especially seeking ideas on topics of interest, resource speakers, and 
evaluating lists of participants; and (iii) a university or post-graduate degree in accounting, 
business, economics, or related fields. The coordinator will be in charge of all logistical and

(iii)  assist  in  selecting  participants,  preparing  the  agenda,  and  disseminating 
information among participants; and 
(iv)  perform administrative and ad hoc support to ADB staff and international staff.
